slides.content:
Geometry is the study of shapes, sizes, and spaces. It's all around us - in buildings, furniture, art, and nature!

In this lesson, you'll learn:

  • Basic shapes and their properties
  • Types of angles
  • Perimeter and how to calculate it
  • Area and how to find it
  • Real-world geometry applications
slides.tip: Look around you - geometry is everywhere! From the screen you're reading on to the shape of your room.

slides.title: Basic Shapes & Properties
slides.content:
Let's learn about common 2D (flat) shapes:

Triangle - 3 sides, 3 angles

  • All angles add up to 180Â°
  • Types: Equilateral (all sides equal), Isosceles (2 sides equal), Scalene (all sides different)

Quadrilaterals - 4 sides, 4 angles

  • Square: 4 equal sides, 4 right angles
  • Rectangle: Opposite sides equal, 4 right angles
  • Parallelogram: Opposite sides parallel and equal
  • Trapezoid: One pair of parallel sides

Circle - Perfectly round

  • Radius: Distance from center to edge
  • Diameter: Distance across (2 Ã— radius)
slides.example:
Shape Examples:

  • Triangle: Road signs, roof of a house
  • Square: Floor tiles, chessboard
  • Rectangle: Door, book, phone screen
  • Circle: Wheel, coin, clock face

slides.title: Understanding Angles
slides.content:
An angle is formed when two lines meet at a point.

Types of Angles:

  • Right Angle: Exactly 90Â° (like a corner of a book)
  • Acute Angle: Less than 90Â° (sharp angle)
  • Obtuse Angle: More than 90Â° but less than 180Â° (wide angle)
  • Straight Angle: Exactly 180Â° (straight line)

Measuring Angles:

  • Use a protractor
  • Unit of measurement: degrees (Â°)
slides.example:
Real-Life Angles:

  • Right angle (90Â°): Corner of a wall
  • Acute angle: Roof of a house
  • Obtuse angle: Opened book
  • Straight angle (180Â°): Flat horizon

Fun Fact: A full rotation is 360Â°!
slides.tip: Right angles are everywhere - look for them in corners of rooms, books, and screens!

slides.title: What is Perimeter?
slides.content:
Perimeter is the distance around a shape. Think of it as the length of fence needed to go all around a field.

How to Find Perimeter:

Add up the lengths of all sides!

Formulas:

  • Square: P = 4 Ã— side
  • Rectangle: P = 2 Ã— (length + width)
  • Triangle: P = sideâ‚ + sideâ‚‚ + sideâ‚ƒ
  • Any shape: Add all sides together
slides.example:
Example: Rectangle

Length = 8 meters, Width = 5 meters

Method 1: Add all sides

P = 8 + 5 + 8 + 5 = 26 meters

Method 2: Use formula

P = 2 Ã— (8 + 5) = 2 Ã— 13 = 26 meters

Example: Square

Side = 6 centimeters

P = 4 Ã— 6 = 24 centimeters
slides.tip: Perimeter is always measured in linear units: cm, m, km, inches, feet, etc.

slides.title: What is Area?
slides.content:
Area is the amount of space inside a shape. Think of it as how much paint you need to cover a surface.

Example: Rectangle

A = 10 Ã— 4 = 40 square meters (mÂ²)

Example: Triangle

A = Â½ Ã— 8 Ã— 5 = Â½ Ã— 40 = 20 cmÂ²

slides.tip: Area is in SQUARE units because you're measuring a flat surface (length Ã— width)!

slides.title: Perimeter vs Area
slides.content:
Don't confuse perimeter and area! They measure different things:

Perimeter:

  • Distance AROUND a shape
  • One-dimensional (just length)
  • Units: cm, m, km (linear)
  • Think: Fence around a field

Area:

  • Space INSIDE a shape
  • Two-dimensional (length Ã— width)
  • Units: cmÂ², mÂ², kmÂ² (square)
  • Think: Paint to cover a floor
slides.example:
Example: Garden Plot

Length = 12 meters, Width = 8 meters

Perimeter (fence needed):

P = 2 Ã— (12 + 8) = 40 meters of fence

Area (soil to fill):

A = 12 Ã— 8 = 96 square meters of soil

Remember: Same shape, but different measurements for different purposes!
slides.tip: Ask yourself: Am I measuring AROUND (perimeter) or INSIDE (area)?

slides.title: Geometry in Ghana
slides.content:
Geometry is used everywhere in daily life in Ghana:

  • Building: Calculating land area (plots), room dimensions
  • Farming: Measuring farm land, calculating field perimeter for fencing
  • Market: Measuring fabric (area), calculating rope length (perimeter)
  • Sports: Football field dimensions, basketball court area
  • Art: Kente cloth patterns, Adinkra symbols

Practice Problems:

  1. A square room has sides of 5 meters. Find perimeter and area.
  2. A rectangular farm is 20m Ã— 15m. Find area.
  3. A triangle has base 10cm and height 6cm. Find area.
slides.example:
Answers:

  1. Perimeter = 4 Ã— 5 = 20 meters
    Area = 5 Ã— 5 = 25 mÂ²
  2. Area = 20 Ã— 15 = 300 mÂ²
  3. Area = Â½ Ã— 10 Ã— 6 = 30 cmÂ²

Real Problem:

A farmer wants to fence a rectangular plot 30m Ã— 20m. How much fence is needed?

P = 2 Ã— (30 + 20) = 100 meters of fence
slides.tip: Practice geometry by measuring real things around you - your room, books, furniture!
